main_text:
The Arguments for Occasionalism || The “Conservation is but Continuous Creation” (CCC) Argument
3.4 The “Conservation is but Continuous Creation” (CCC) Argument

The main strategy of this argument is to establish the thesis of
occasionalism by drawing out the implications of the commonly held
theological principle that “conservation is but continuous
 creation.”[24]
 If the main premise of the NNC argument—that is, the premise
that genuine causation just consists in necessary
connection—would have been resisted by many concurrentists, the
strategy behind the CCC argument holds more promise in that the CCC
thesis was widely accepted by the majority of theists in our time
period, including the concurrentists. The issue of how to interpret
the CCC thesis, however, is at the center of the dispute, since
occasionalists like Malebranche deny creaturely causation
because they accept the CCC thesis, while concurrentists like
Leibniz affirm genuine creaturely causation despite upholding
the CCC thesis. 

Before proceeding further, we might briefly examine why the CCC thesis
was so broadly accepted as the orthodox view, by considering what
implications the rejection of the CCC thesis was thought to entail.
The most significant implication of rejecting the CCC thesis, from the
perspective of the proponents of the CCC thesis, is the consequence
that divine causal activity at creation is markedly different from
divine causal activity in moments of conservation, such that the
difference is sufficient to deny the identity of the two acts. Hence,
conservation is not continuous creation. An intuitive way of
cashing out this difference, which indeed is how “mere
conservationists” such as Durandus proceeded, is to think that
while God does everything there is to be done, causally speaking, at
the moment of creation, God does less in subsequent moments of
conservation such that God merely conserves the creatures in
existence. How is God doing less in conservation, according to the
conservationist? In moments of conservation, if the event that is
caused is a non-miraculous natural event, the direct,
immediate cause of this event is a creaturely cause, and not
divine. God is involved, even for the conservationist, but only in a
mediated, indirect manner—God works in the background,
as it were, keeping the creaturely cause in existence, allowing the
creature to exercise its causal powers in a direct, immediate fashion.
For instance, if the fire of a gas range causes the water in the
coffee pot to boil, the boiling of the water is directly and
immediately caused by the fire, even if it is fully granted that the
existence of the fire must be directly conserved by God. Thus, God, in
keeping the fire in existence, which in turn allows the fire to boil
the water directly and immediately, is mediately and remotely involved
in the boiling of the water, according to the mere conservationist.
God is merely conserving the fire (and water) and not
directly causing the water to boil. From our contemporary perspective,
this indirect, mediated involvement on the part of God might seem
sufficient to give divine causality its due place in nature. But the
theistic philosophers of the late Scholastic and early modern period
found this way of securing the role of divine causality theologically
insufficient and suspect. The main worry appears to have been that to
think that the dependence of creatures on God is somehow reduced, once
creation has past, fundamentally misrepresents the critical dependence
creatures have on God throughout their existence, be it
creation or conservation. Because in terms of creaturely dependence
conservation and creation are fundamentally the same, these
philosophers seemed to have been thinking, what other differences
there might be between conservation and creation, these differences
are negligible. It is from this perspective that the orthodox view was
to affirm the identity between conservation and
 creation.[25]


An early version of something close to the core idea behind the CCC
argument emerges in the views of al-Ash‘ari (873–935), the
founder of Ash‘arite school. As Perler and Rudolph have argued,
according to al-Ash‘ari, God rearranges the atoms that make up
this world anew at every instant, and in so doing God continuously
creates the accidents that inhere in these atomic substances (Perler
and Rudolph 2000, 28–62). The view seems to have been one where
the accidents of a substance possess only a momentary existence.
Hence, at every instant, God brings about the accidents that inhere in
the substances by continuously recreating these modes. If God sustains
the existence of the atoms themselves, while continuously recreating
all of their modes, then, barring causal overdetermination, the
occasionalist conclusion that God is the only genuine cause does seem
to follow from this interpretation of divine conservative
activity.

On the European continent, the most artful presentation of the CCC
argument is found in Malebranche. But the argument is not thought to
have originated with Malebranche, and it has typically been traced
back to Descartes, though whether he was himself indeed an
occasionalist is some matter of controversy, as noted earlier. One of
the main texts surrounding this controversy comes from the Third
Meditation:

… [I]t does not follow from the fact that I existed a little
while ago that I must exist now, unless there is some cause which as
it were creates me afresh at this moment—that is, which
preserves me. For it is quite clear to anyone … that the same
power and action are needed to preserve anything at each individual
moment of its duration as would be required to create that thing anew
if it were not yet in existence. Hence the distinction between
preservation and creation is only a conceptual one, and this is one of
the things that are evident by the natural light. (AT VII 49/CSM II
 33)[26]


Taken in isolation, this passage does suggest that Descartes took our
souls to be continuously created by God in a way that would preclude
any genuine causal activity on our part. For if, in initially creating
of my soul—that is, in its creation ex nihilo—God
brings about both the existence of my soul and its modes or
modification, then, since the “same power and action” of
God is required in preserving my existence subsequent to creation
ab initio, God would be the sole causal agent that brings
about my preserved existence with the modes I possess. But to conclude
on the basis of this interpretation that Descartes was an
occasionalist would be premature, since there is a good supply of
other texts that suggest Descartes’ affirmation of our genuine
causal efficacy.

In contrast, Louis de la Forge’s commitment to the occasionalist
thesis, at least with regard to bodies, seems unquestionable. For he
makes explicit the critical claim that God’s causal activity of
producing a body is inseparable from his producing the particular
modes of the body in question:

Not only must [God] continue to produce [a body], if he wants it to
persevere in existence; but in addition, because he cannot create it
everywhere nor outside of any particular place, he must himself put it
in place [lieu] B if he wants it there. (TEH 240)


The central idea is that God’s causal activity with regard to
the production of a body is an “all or nothing” affair, in
the sense that if God produces the body, God produces it with all of
its specific modes or properties. In other words, though God need not
create a body, as long as he does create or conserve it, he cannot do
so without bringing about its specific spatial properties or modes.
Why, we might ask, is this the case? Even if one grants that there can
be no abstract or general Cartesian body, as it were—that is, a
body that is extended in general without any specific spatial
properties or modes—such that even God could not create such a
body in the abstract, the concurrents could still wonder, why is it
the case that the cause that gives the esse to a given body
must also be the cause that produces its specific modes and properties
as well? It is here that the CCC thesis provides the missing link. For
if conservation is but continuous creation, in the sense that the
character and degree of dependence is identical in the two cases, then
insofar as there was total dependence at creation, there would have to
be total dependence in conservation. Occasionalism with regard to
bodies would follow. Given that God has a monopoly over producing both
the body itself and its modes, no other cause is operative in bringing
about any aspect of the world. Conservation is but continuous
creation.

At this point, we might want to consider the possibility of
overdetermination. Could we not think that some creaturely effects are
overdetermined in conservation? That is, might we not grant that God
is the total and direct cause of a creature’s modes but also
hold that the creature causes its modes as well such that certain
effects are causally overdetermined? Moreover, if it is only the modes
of the creature that are overdetermined, then it seems as though there
is no violation of the central tenet that God is the unique causal
source of the esse that creatures have. As we have discussed
earlier, divine causal power importantly involves that of keeping the
being or esse of the creature in existence, and even the
conservationist grants that the role of a conserving cause—that
is, the causal power of keeping the being of creatures in
existence—is the unique prerogative of God as the causa
secundum esse. That is, all parties in this dispute concerning
the issue of secondary causation in nature agree, regardless of their
views about the reality of creaturely causal powers, that the being or
esse of a creature when the creature is conserved is just as
dependent on God as when the creature is created ex nihilo.
God is the unique creative and conserving cause of any being or
esse in this world.

The overdetermination of modes, thus, cannot be ruled out on the mere
grounds that such overdetermination involves a malignant type of
causal overreach on the part of creatures, overflowing into the
exclusive divine realm of providing esse. For the proponents
of overdetermination are taking the creaturely power to be restricted
to that of bringing about a creature’s modes. The creature
therefore would not share in the power of the causa secundum
esse, and what power the creature would have to produce modes or
modifications would be effective only insofar as the creature’s
being or esse has been produced by God. Hence, the critical
dependence of the creature’s esse or being on God is
maintained. It is in this sense that cases of overdetermination of
modes might present a noteworthy challenge to the advocates of
occasionalism arguing on the basis of the CCC thesis.

But this is not to say that the occasionalist is left without possible
responses to this challenge. First of all, the occasionalists might
suggest that such overdetermination implies that God is engaging in
needlessly redundant causal behavior. Not only would God be producing
the modes himself but he would also be producing the causal power of
the creature that is an overdetermining cause of these modes. And the
occasionalist could go on to argue that such redundancy is
problematic. Second, and more importantly, if a core intuition behind
the CCC thesis, as pointed out earlier, is the point that a
creature’s dependence on God when it is conserved is no less
than when it is initially created ex nihilo, then we might
think that the overdetermination of an effect in conservation
conflicts with this symmetric dependency. For if some effects are
overdetermined in conservation, then with regard to those effects of
the creature, the creature’s dependence is in some significant
sense less than in creation, since the effects would come about even
if the mode-producing causal activity of God were absent. The fact
that the occurrence of these effects is causally guaranteed through
overdetermination—particularly in virtue of the creature’s
productive power—could be thought to be inconsistent with the
radical dependence of creatures expressed in the doctrine of creation
ex nihilo. A different way to put the point would be to argue
that the view that allows for overdetermination in the production of
modes would come dangerously close to mere conservationism in that the
creaturely cause on the overdetermination view is capable of directly
and immediately bringing about the mode in question. For the
overdetermination scenario suggests that even if God were not to
produce the mode directly, the mode would come about from the
creature’s power in virtue of God conserving the creature with
its power. Thus, insofar as the creature is an overdetermining cause,
its causal power, in effect, is of a type that is typically endorsed
by
 conservationists.[27]
 Though neither La Forge nor Malebranche directly address the
possibility of overdetermination, the following passage from La Forge
seems to support the view that this intuition about the symmetry of
dependence is indeed part of his motivation behind his endorsement of
the CCC thesis:

It was necessary for [God] to employ his omnipotent power in order to
bring all of Nature out of nothing. … It would all return to
nothing if God ceased bringing it out of nothing at each moment that
he conserves
 it.[28]


As we have seen, the success of the CCC argument relies heavily on the
claim that the act of creation ex nihilo and the act of
conservation are indistinguishable in terms of both the dependence of
the creature on God and the role and content of divine causal
activity. That is, the two acts are qualitatively identical in terms
of what God is doing, causally speaking. Malebranche reinforces this
claim in his Dialogues by emphasizing that God’s causal
activity of sustaining the being or esse of a creature and
his causal activity of bringing about the modes of a creature cannot
come apart:

Creation does not pass, because the conservation of creatures
is—on the part of God—simply a continuous creation, a
single volition subsisting and operating continuously. Now, God can
neither conceive nor consequently will that a body exist nowhere, nor
that it does not stand in certain relations of distance to other
bodies. Thus, God cannot will that this armchair exist, and by this
volition create or conserve it, without situating it here, there, or
elsewhere. … Now it is a contradiction that God wills this
armchair to exist, unless He wills it to exist somewhere and unless,
by the efficacy of His will, He puts it there, conserves it there,
creates it there. (OCM XII 160/ Dialogues
115–6)


Malebranche here is assuming that in the case of creation ex
nihilo God is the cause of not only the being or esse of
a creature but also its modes—presumably because no other
possible cause actually exists prior to the act of creation ex
nihilo. So by taking God’s conserving activity to be
qualitatively identical to his activity as creator ex nihilo,
Malebranche appears to arguing that even in cases where the creatures
are conserved, God is the unique cause of both their esse and
modes. Since the modes of a creature cannot in principle have been
causally overdetermined in the case of creation ex
nihilo—for creation ex nihilo suggests that no
cause exists prior to the act of creation—if the
creature’s dependence on God in instances of conservation is
identical to the instance of creation ex nihilo, then there
can be no overdetermination in the production of modes in cases of
conservation. Now the concurrentist might reply at this point that
concurrentists deny overdetermining creaturely causes as well, since
their point is that the creature is a concurring cause of the
modes of the creature: the causal contribution of neither God nor the
creature are redundant, since both are necessary in some manner. But
notice that if it is indeed the case that the act of creation ex
nihilo should be understood to imply that God is the unique cause
of both the esse and modes of the creature, and if
conservation is qualitatively identical to continuous creation ex
nihilo in causally relevant respects, then the concurrentist
would have to either reject the CCC thesis or suggest a different
account of what is going on at creation ex
 nihilo.[29]
 For if this way of understanding continuous creation rules out
overdetermining causes, it also rules out concurring causes. 

However, some have suggested that identifying conservation with
creation ex nihilo this closely effectively pushes us to
regard conservation as continuous recreation, where the
creature that is supposedly “conserved” falls out of
existence instantaneously before it is repeatedly
 recreated.[30]
 Interestingly, this “continuous recreation” reading seems
well-motivated from the occasionalist perspective. If one wants to
enforce a strict identity between conservation and creation, why not
go all out and take conservation to be recreation ex nihilo,
in which case the absence of any cause other than God will be
guaranteed, thereby automatically securing the occasionalist thesis?
On this reading as continuous recreation, conservation is in fact the
continuous resuscitation of the creature from the void of
non-existence, into which the creature is thrust instantaneously after
its momentary existence. Some, such as Winkler, have suggested that
the continuous recreation reading of the CCC thesis would indeed do
the work of establishing occasionalism, since at every moment of
conservation, there would literally be no creature around, as it were,
to cooperate as a concurring
 cause.”[31]
 Continuous creation as recreation, however, raises a number of
concerns, including the question of whether the transtemporal identity
of creatures can be maintained. For, on the recreation model, the
previous creature ex hypothesi goes out of existence, and
another one is created anew and the two would then seem to be
numerically distinct. 

Perhaps more serious is the following type of challenge by the
concurrentist. The concurrentist at this point might protest and
question whether and why the identity of conservation and creation
need be taken in this manner. Given that the concurrentist wishes to
maintain theological orthodoxy and endorse the CCC thesis as well, the
concurrentist might suggest that an alternative understanding of the
identity between creation and conservation is available in the
following manner: to say that conservation is but continuous creation
just is to say that the act of creation and conservation is but a
numerically single act on the part of God, and thus it need not be the
case that what God does, causally speaking, remains qualitatively the
same throughout this one, continuous act. For example, one might take
a single, continuous walk during which the pace is at times brisk, at
times leisurely, but such difference in terms of exertion throughout
the walk does not split the walk into two distinct
 acts.[32]
 On such a model, the concurrentist could argue that she also agrees
that conservation is continuous with creation and thus conservation
and creation comprise a single, identical act, but the affirmation of
the CCC thesis, cashed out in this way, need not imply that there is
no creaturely contribution in moments of conservation. God, on this
“continuous maintenance” reading (Winkler 2011, 301)
maintains the creature throughout its existence in a single, unified
act, but what God does at the initial point of creation differs from
what God does when he merely conserves the creature. Note that this
“continuous maintenance” reading targets not only the
“continuous recreation” reading but “qualitative
identity” reading as well. For the latter two readings share the
intuition that the identity in question is one in which divine causal
contribution be thought to be qualitatively the same, regardless of
whether it be in the form of recreation or not. 

The dialectic then at this point can be understood as a debate between
two fundamentally different readings of the CCC thesis. On the one
hand, there are those, like Malebranche, who take the CCC thesis as a
premise toward occasionalism in that the identity in question is one
of qualitative identity in the sense that what God does causally
speaking at creation ex nihilo is the same as what God does
in conservation—let’s call this the “qualitative
identity” reading. On the other hand, there are who read the
identity as a mere numerical identity, wherein God continuously
maintains the creature throughout its existence, but what God does
qualitatively at creation is different from what God does in
conservation. God does less in conservation than at creation, but the
acts comprise one continuous whole—let’s call this the
“numerical identity” reading. If the numerical identity
reading was more comfortable to those divine concurrents who wanted to
both endorse the CCC thesis and allow for genuine causation
at the creaturely level, one might think that the contribution of
occasionalists like La Forge and Malebranche to the debate was to
presenting a strong case as to why the qualitative identity reading
ought to be preferred as the correct interpretation of the CCC thesis.
Here actually is Malebranche pressing precisely this case:

“The moment of creation has passed!” But if this moment
does not pass, then you are in a spot, and will have to yield.
Therefore take note. God wills that a certain kind of world exist. His
will is omnipotent, and this world is thus created. Let God no longer
will there to be a world, and it is thereby annihilated. For the world
assuredly depends on the will of the creator. If the world subsists,
it is because God continues to will its existence. Thus, the
conservation of creatures is, on the part of God, nothing but their
continued creation. I say on the part of God who acts. For on the part
of creatures there appears to be a difference, since by the act of
creation they pass from nothingness to being, whereas by the act of
conservation they continue to be. But in essence the act of creation
does not cease, because in God creation and conservation are but a
single volition which, consequently, is necessarily followed by the
same effects. (Dialogues 112, my emphasis)


Note in the last sentence that the identity of the volition is cashed
out in terms of the identity of the effects, which supports the view
that for Malebranche, the proper reading of the CCC thesis is the
qualitative identity reading. For the numerical identity reading
entails that God’s effect in conservation ought to be
distinguished from God’s effect at creation in that God does
less in conservation than creation.

Lastly, we note that, while La Forge appears to have limited his
occasionalism to extended substances and held that we as minds are
causally active in producing our ideas (TEH 166), Malebranche
extends his occasionalism to thinking substances. Consider the
following passage from the Treatise on Ethics (1684):

Glory and Honor belong to God alone. Toward Him alone, all the
movements of all minds ought to tend, because only in Him does power
reside. All willing by creatures is inefficacious in itself. Only
He who gives being could be able to give the ways of being, since the
ways of being are nothing but beings themselves, in this or that
fashion. Nothing is more evident to one who knows how to consult
the inner truth. For what is more evident than that if God, for
example, keeps a body always in one place, then no creature could move
it to another? Or that no man could even move his own arm unless God
wills to concur in doing that which ungrateful and stupid man thinks
he is doing by himself? And the same goes for the ways of being of
minds. If God keeps or creates the soul in a way of being which
afflicts it, such as with pain, no mind can deliver itself therefrom,
nor make itself to feel pleasure thereby, unless God concurs with it
to carry out its desires. (OCM XI 160/TE 147, my
emphasis)


Here we get something close to a generalized version of the key claim
of the CCC argument in the Dialogues that God cannot will
that an extended substance exist, “without at the same time
willing that it exist either here or there and without His will
placing it somewhere” (OCM XII 156/Dialogues
110): only he who gives being could be able to give the ways of being.
And, importantly, this principle is said to be applicable to the
“ways of being of
 minds.”[33]
 In effect, we are presented with an explicit denial of the
possibility that God’s sustaining activity of the being or
esse of a creature can be separated from his activity of
bringing about the modes of the creature, regardless of whether the
creature is an extended or thinking substance. Hence, the CCC argument
seems to be fully applicable to the modes or ways of the being of the
minds, just like bodies.

Malebranche’s extension of the thesis of occasionalism to
thinking substances, as presented here in the Treatise on
Ethics, is not an aberration. In one of his most careful
statements about how minds relate to his occasionalism, Malebranche
claims as follows:

I agree that God is the sole author of all substances and of all their
modes, that He is the author of all beings: not only of all bodies but
of all minds. But be careful: I understand by a mode of a
substance only that which cannot change without there being some real
or physical change in the substance of which it is the mode. …
Once again, I agree that God is the sole efficacious cause of all the
real changes that take place in the world (Prémotion
Physique, OC XVI 40; the translation is from Kremer 2000,
210–11).


Here, once again, we get an explicit statement that God is the sole
author of all substances and their modes. Note, however, that
Malebranche is careful to specify what he means by a
“mode” of a substance. This clarification is motivated by
the attempt to make room for a kind of power within minds or thinking
substances that will allow for the attribution of freedom and moral
responsibility to them. This power of consent or withholding of
consent is further developed in the following:

There are in the soul two different powers or activities. The first is
properly only the action of God … [who] continually creates the
soul with the invincible desire to be happy, or continually moves it
toward the good in general. But the second … which is the
essence of freedom, is … very different from the first. It
consists in a true power, not to produce, by its own efficacy, new
modifications in itself, that is, new interesting perceptions or new
movements in the will, but … a true power of the soul to
suspend or to give its consent to the movements that follow naturally
upon interesting perceptions. (OCM XVI 46–7; the
translation is from Kremer 2000, 1999)


Interestingly enough, this power of the soul is described as not being
a power that produces modifications, which is an expression
of Malebranche’s attempt to reconcile the positing of such
powers in minds with his occasionalism about minds. That is, insofar
as all powers that bring about changes in modes are in God, and merely
non-modal powers are in the creature, then Malebranche seems to be
thinking that such non-modal powers of creatures are consistent with
his occasionalism. This, however, raises the question of whether such
non-modal powers are robust enough to anchor the free will and moral
responsibility of thinking
 substances.[34]

If we bracket the issue of how to render a full-blown occasionalism
with a sufficiently robust account of free will, then, as we have
hopefully seen, the CCC argument is a fairly powerful argument as an
argument for global occasionalism.
section_title: 3.4 The “Conservation is but Continuous Creation” (CCC) Argument
